activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#10585
activity.text:
**Approach**

For different locations within a facility (floors, ward, etc) can have different variety of beds (ICU, Standard etc.)
In location form we can add a Input field for user to select the type of bed , and conditional field to select number of beds of selected category (by default add 1 for the type of bed entered)

we don't require to send the array in network request as it will create memory overhead, we can only send type of bed and number to add,

then make api call, backend will update database to add new beds

**Example**
if user selects type of bed - ICU, number - 3
in backend, if say, 3 beds already exist for ICU, it should push ICU-4, ICU-5, ICU-6 for that location otherwise ICU-1, ICU-2, ICU-3 in database (and update parent organizations also at that time)

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#10401
activity.text: We can definitely track the errors like that but, these errors are for the "hardcoded-strings" it is not including the translation keys that are undefined in en.json Refer : https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-plugin-i18next Proof : 1. WITHOUT undefined check - only hardcode string errors - count 1429 ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8162edeb-22ab-4244-8ec4-b5dc61f2230e) 2. WITH undefined check - include undefined keys errors - count 1453 (24 extra) ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9cda434d-01ab-4043-a50e-b072c89deb2b) 3. ONLY undefined check - count 24 ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/19eaf104-9e18-43ab-be08-7f8bf5db4399) 24 undefined strings output using a script to solve the issue before build we should be doing the third check only right, because first check has no significance because it is also checking for hardcode strings inside className, variant, size, href etc. so should we use the [no-undefined-translation-keys](https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-plugin-i18next-no-undefined-translation-keys) plugin or both? @rithviknishad

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#10220
activity.text:
> > > Hmm, let's not do this - on first load of any query, the feedback is not immediate (as supposed to with the skeleton loaders) so it looks off.
> > 
> > for the first load skeleton loaders are displayed as `isLoading` is true, else it is false once data is fetched/refetched. Please check deployed Preview i have handled that case.
> 
> To clarify; I meant the first time it fetches the data (navigating to 2nd page, for example, fetches the data because the data isn't available in cache). If you go to page 1 and then navigate back to page 2, there's no fetching as data is cached.
> 
> I've checked the preview - to illustrate my point, check the recording you posted above, when you go from page 1 to 2 the first time, skeleton loader won't be triggered as there's placeholder data (page 1).

but that's what the issue was about, even when it is fetching the data for first time for page 2, it shows data for page 1 (as placeholder) and no switching between skeletons and pages back and forth
- show skeletons only when none of the page is fetched
I thought @rithviknishad got that.
but it's okay if that was not the desired UIüòä

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#10220
activity.text:
> Hmm, let's not do this - on first load of any query, the feedback is not immediate (as supposed to with the skeleton loaders) so it looks off.

for the first load skeleton loaders are displayed as `isLoading` is true, else it is false once data is fetched.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/leaderboard#602
activity.text:
In this approach
1. Fetch all members of organization 
2. Fetch all repos of organization 
3. Fetch all open PRs of each repository 
4. Filter the PRs whose author is not a member & not blacklisted
5. Fetch all commits (excluding merge commit) through REST API
6. Add the user

I ran the scrapers, and they ran perfectly fine.
I used a combination of GraphQL and REST to optimize the rate limits, i.e., 5000 points/hour for GraphQL and 5000 requests/hour for REST.

@rithviknishad if these changes are applicable or need any changes please let me know
I will move ahead with implementing the types.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/leaderboard#601
activity.text:
> Not a fan of N+1 approach. If this was deployed for a much bigger github org, which has too many forks, fetching commit history of each fork's branches might go off the limits pretty quickly.
> 
> Let's do a 2 part PR. Let's first get the org's repo commits tracked first. We can figure out something for the fork's. We only ideally care about commits pushed directly to default branch and commits pushed to PR branches alone.

https://github.com/ohcnetwork/leaderboard/pull/602#issuecomment-2581764151

activity.title: ohcnetwork/leaderboard#602
activity.text:
For each forked repo -
- First, we can get the commits in the default branch
- Then get all PRs associated with that repo,
- finally, get the commits of pr.merged_at(for closed) prs and open prs
 
This we narrow down our hunt to just the commits that were merged or open in a PR, commits pushed to any branch not were not associated with any PR will be ignored.

This can reduce time complexity to some extend, @rithviknishad

activity.title: ohcnetwork/leaderboard#602
activity.text: Add support for tracking commits pushed to branch (Forked)

activity.title: ohcnetwork/leaderboard#424
activity.text:
> How are you planning to solve this though? Does GitHub supports this via their API?

Here's my approach for implementing this feature
- Take inspiration from [Leaderboard](https://github.com/ohcnetwork/leaderboard/blob/ddbdd014c1849908118e8c90df53d305e829ab23/app/leaderboard/%5Bduration%5D/Leaderboard.tsx#L48) page, but UI of search bars will be similar to the one shown in issue description.
- Take input through [Select](https://github.com/ohcnetwork/leaderboard/blob/ddbdd014c1849908118e8c90df53d305e829ab23/components/Select.tsx#L8) and update the search params using `updateSearchParams` as defined in Leaderboard
- Fetch all repos of the org(sort by lastUpdatedAt) using GraphQL and set them as options of Select 
- Fetch the events of org using pagination, max we can fetch is 300 from last 90 days max.
- Filter the events first by `repository(s)` and then by `Event(s)` based on search params
                  
@rithviknishad, if this approach looks good, please assign me this issue, I'll proceed with the implementation

currently we are not parsing `pushEvents` in [parseEvents](https://github.com/ohcnetwork/leaderboard/blob/46eda0a118a2f084727bfafb2249c5ade02dd9f3/scraper/src/github-scraper/parseEvents.ts#L149), if we do we'll get `forkedCommits` type of `Activity` for core-team members, because this is what [fetchEvents](https://github.com/ohcnetwork/leaderboard/blob/46eda0a118a2f084727bfafb2249c5ade02dd9f3/scraper/src/github-scraper/fetchEvents.ts#L14s) fetches.
we'll write algo for fetching pushEvents from forked repos, and push it in existing `Activity[]` for users and sort them, or do we really need to sort them? may be because that scraper will push on top of existing Activities (Comment, Issue..) from existing scrapers.
